The hair on the back of my neck stood on end.  How in the hell had this monster found me?  My heart took off like Hermes in a foot race.  I looked down at Simon's body, he was unconscious but alive, that was one good thing.

"You smell lovely, little one," he said.  God, this guy was nuts on top of being a demon.  Great.

"Thank you," I said, kneeling down to try and wake Simon.  As soon as my hand touched his shoulder his hand wrapped around my wrist in a death grip.  I looked in his face and saw nothing but terror.

"Gypsy, run," he whispered so softly that I could barely hear him, "it's him.  It's the boy.  It's one of the Twins, Gypsy!"  He was all but screaming at the end.

The male twin, the father of every vampire walking the earth.  We are so screwed. How in the hell was I supposed to fight this?  I've got to get us out of here I thought but I wasn't sure I could.  He was so big and so strong.  I just didn't think I could do it.

"Don't bother running.  I'll just follow you again," he said still standing in the door way.  He hadn't moved at all.  "Why were you following me?"

"Because you're killing people.  You have to stop."

"Why?  Humans are just food for our kind.  Do we not kill that which we eat?"

"There are other ways, Lord Father," Simon said softly from the floor.  "We live in harmony with the humans now.  We do not have to hide ourselves anymore."

Something about what Simon said pissed the demon off.  he threw his head back and roared, the sound was a blood curdling bellow.  As he roared, the same large leathery wings sprouted from his back.  His wings beat against the air and his feet slowly left the ground.  My god, he was flying.  Flying!

I grabbed Simon's hand and dragged him to his feet.  We were getting out of there.  We ran out the back door.  Simon lead us straight towards the back fence.  I wasn't sure what he was planning, if he thought we were just going to run straight through it, until he yelled jump.  Jump?  What do I look like?  A kangaroo?  I didn't know what he was thinking but I jumped anyway.

I felt the muscles in my legs bunch, coiling like a spring.  With barely an effort I pushed off straight up in the air.  before I could blink I was soaring 30ft above the ground.  I didn't think anything could have surprised me more than the fact that Burns was on of the Twins.  Boy, was I wrong.  I could fly!  Holy shit, I could fly!  This must be what Icarus felt like before the sun melted his wings.  For the span of one heartbeat I felt amazing, like I could take on all of Hell and win.  That thought brought me quickly back to reality; one piece of Hell was right behind me and I don't think he was please with the path his "children" had taken in his absence.

What was I supposed to do about this?  So, I could fly?  If he got his hands on me he could throw me around like a rag doll.  What good was flying against strength like that.  I had a thought, I wasn't sure it would work but a banshee and a werewolf added to the mix just might even the odds.  I had to get us there, I looked down at the city spread out below us and tried to figure out where I was.  Once I spotted something I recognized I made my way from there.  I wasn't really having any problem with flying; landing was a completely different story.  To be completely honest, I fell on my face.  I didn't wast any time getting up though.  Before even half a second had passed I was through the door.  Vince caught me this time and he didn't fall over.

"Get ready for it!" I yelled unwinding from Vince and turning to face the door.  I could see debris being stirred as Burns winged his way in.  "All hell is about to break lose."

Simon and I crouched low.  Vince shifted, the fur of his wolf flowing gracefully over his skin.  Michaela trilled slightly and Polasky just squared his shoulders.

"Polasky, what are you doing?"

"Oh no, girl, I'm not letting my team walk into the jaws of hell without me."  I could only shrug; once Polasky made up his mind there was no changing it.

I had only enough time for one more thought before we turned as a group to face the bad guy.  At least my sweet, loveable, entirely too humanly breakable mother wasn't here.  After that I could think of nothing but surviving the fight.

I was crouching in the shadow of an old oak tree with my lunch still slurping out of the bag and down my throat when I saw him. I'd spent the last two weeks looking for the man walking into the building in front of me. He didn't smell right though; he didn't smell human. I caught the faint but very distinct scent of sulfur on the air. Demon, I thought, but how? They're not supposed to be able to come above and they're definitely not supposed to look so damned yummy.

The man in front of me was immensely tall, pale blond, his face was well built like an artist had worked on him especially. His deep set eyes gave him a look almost of sorrow but there was something in them that warned that he had never felt sorrow over anything and never would.

I blinked and came back to reality there was something vaguely familiar about this mark in a very unsettling way. Almost like a nightmare that drifts away when you wake up, you can only remember pieces. Something about him made me afraid, badly afraid. Whatever it was, I had to ignore it; I had a job to do. I had to bring him down.

I flipped open the file on my lap Christian Burns had been a very bad boy lately. Three deaths already known to be his work and four more believed to be his. Again the cops were at a loss. He looked like just another human but there definitely was something other about him. He always seemed to know when the police were coming for him and was never there. The bodies just kept piling up.

Since they couldn't catch him, Tampa PD called Polasky. The case got passed down to me. So far I hadn't been able to even catch a glimpse of him, until tonight. The picture didn't do him justice. But finally here he was. It was just too easy, it wasn't right; I could feel it deep in my gut.

I finished off the bag with a gulp and stuffed it back in the pack I'd brought with me. I stood slowly looking over the building Burns had walked into. A simple looking warehouse, one large door and a smaller one. Red bricks made up the face. I could get in easy enough but it would be loud. I moved out of the shadow to look around the rest of the building. I could take my time, I had all night. As I stepped into the light of the street lamp, something shot out and grabbed my throat.

The face was in shadow but I could smell the sulfur again. Somehow, Burns had gotten the drop on me. He stepped in to the circle of light and smiled at me. A sweet smile that said plainly that he was the cat and I was the canary. I tried to break free but he was so strong. I hadn't found much that was stronger than me since I had become a vampire. I definitely didn't like this.

His fingers flexed slightly and my air was completely cut off. He smiled again, and then he spoke. "Silly child, did you really thing you could hide from me, the oldest of you?" His voice was smooth and rich as fresh butter. He threw me back from him with just a flick of his wrist, the sulfur smell getting stronger, he was angry. I had found him when no one else could.

I hit the wall hard enough to crack the bricks and knock the wind out of me. My head snapped back against the wall and I saw stars. In was stunned for barely a moment and when my head cleared, he was waiting for me. I knew I'd never be able to win against him, not alone. I began slowly backing away from him, never looking away. I kept creeping backwards until there was about 100 yards between us and I felt sure I could get away, he was strong but not fast. I stood fully and looked that the man in front of me.

I couldn't believe what I was seeing. The smooth beautiful face was melting away revealing a horrifying image. The true form of Christian Burns was as terrifying as the other was beautiful. Red skin that was lined with deep black scars that looked like claw marks running diagonally across his face. The skin itself looked like leather. Great black leathery wings sprouted from between his shoulders and horns grew from his forehead. I'll admit it, I stopped escaping and stared at the beast in front of me. I screamed, he roared, and I ran like a little dog with my tail between my legs. I didn't know why but I knew if I didn't get out of there, I was dead.

I didn't know where I was going, all I knew is that I had to run. I ended up back at the office. Michaela was there and she caught me as I came through the door. I ran right straight through her and we both hit the ground. I was beyond out of my mind with fear. I tried to tell her what I'd seen but I couldn't make my voice work, all I could do was scream. Polasky came out of his office and helped Michaela carry me to my desk. When I finally screamed myself out and could tell them what had happened there were both silent and pale as death.

"What was it?" Michaela trilled.

"A demon, I think. I didn't think they could come up here."

"Neither did I, girl, neither did I," Polasky said. "This is going to open up a whole heap of trouble for us. if we've got demons walking around that can throw a vamp around like a ragdoll things are going to get real ugly real fast."

Polasky told me to go home, I'd had enough excitement for one night. Instead of going home, I went to Simon's. I just didn't think my mom would understand what had happened tonight. I knew Simon would, I knew he would understand the fear. When I got there I told him everything about Burns that I could remember. He held me while I cried the rest of the terror out and finally stopped shaking. When I looked up his white shirt was stained with the faintly red traces of my tears. All I could so was laugh.

"I'm sorry," I gasped between laughs.

"For what, ma cher?" he asked.

"I ruined your shirt," I howled hysterically laughing. I guess that was the cost of crying non stop for almost an hour. I stopped when someone knocked on the door. My new found paranoia (product of the job) took over and I got ready for a fight. Simon went to answer the door and I could hear his voice faintly as he asked who it was. The next thing I knew Simon was flying backwards to land on his coffee table and Burns was stepping through the walkway into the living room.

"I found you."
 
"Fuck!"  That was all I could say.

Where did we come from?


It was about 4:30 when I woke. I didn't have class that night and I was off work too, so I just let myself lie there and take in my surroundings. I was still at Simon's laying in his glorious bed. I could feel the weight of the bedspread pressing on me. The dream fading from my mind left me slightly uneasy, I'd had the same dream every morning for weeks. A woman and something strange, not a man but I wasn't sure what it was. I would almost say a demon but even that didn't feel right. The dream wasn't just those two though, there was always something evil there too, something different but familiar too.

I could hear Simon moving around somewhere in the house. My mind returned to the present and I discovered that I didn't feel the least bit awkward. Even from this distance I could smell the honey and vanilla scent that had hit me the night before. I still liked it. Underneath that I could smell the deliciously copper scent of heated blood. My mouth suddenly felt like someone had packed it full of cotton. I groaned out loud. Before the sound had finished leaving my mouth Simon was beside the bed. In one hand he held a robe and the other held a large coffee cup full of the viscous, crimson liquid. I took the cup first, letting the blood slide down my throat and sooth the ache there. Finished the rest of the cup, I sighed contentedly and looked up at him. "Hi."

"Good evening, sleepy." The hint of laughter in his voice was just a littler heavier. He smiled at me as he held out the long, black robe that looked suspiciously like silk.

I stood up and stretched muscles that complained only slightly. Simon leaned over and laid a gentle kiss on my shoulder where the evidence of the night before still lay for the world to see. Running one hand down my arm, he smiled and handed me the robe and left the room. The fabric slithered across my skin when I put it around me. Silk, definitely silk. I marveled again at the fact that I was perfectly comfortable with this man who I'd seen maybe two time before the night before.

We talked again, but this time it was me with the questions, and I had a lot of them. Where had he come from? When had he come from? I stood at my window that morning staring out at the yard. There was a slight lightening to the sky in the east, not enough for humans to see but enough to let me know it was almost bed time. I missed the colors of early morning, the way the grass looks when the sun first hits it with the little drops of dew scattered all around. Sighing, I closed the shutters that Mom had had installed on the inside of the windows and then the curtains.

I went over to my bed and in a typical teenage move flopped down on it and lay there staring up at my ceiling. Why did I suddenly feel depressed? I loved my new stronger body and the fact that nothing on earth could really kill me. I liked the fact that most of the bullshit about vampires was just that. I didn’t die at dawn, I actually slept. I could still eat regular food, I just had to have a healthy portion of blood in my daily diet. I just missed the colors of daylight.

“Gypsy?” my mom said from the door. She’d been worried about how I’d been feeling.

“Yeah, Mom. I’m still awake. Come on in.”

“I just wanted to tell you good night, sweetheart.” she said pushing my door open and looking at my window.

“It’s closed, Mom, I’m not suicidal, just trying to adjust and get used to the fact that I’ll never get to feel the sun on my face again.”

“I’m sorry, honey.”

“Mom, I’m kind of tired. Can we talk about this tonight?” I said turning over and getting under the covers. I didn’t want her to see the pinkish tears running down my face.

“Sure, baby.”

I lay there under my blanket thinking about the sun and let sleep wash over me. I dreamed I was laying on the beaches in Clearwater the clear sunlight kissing my skin and turning it a beautiful bronze color. My brother was sitting next me complaining about skin cancer and sunburns. He always burned. Then the dream changed, I was in the backyard with the whole family and my best friend Jackie. Daddy was building a bonfire, I watched as the flames licked up the little teepee of wood he had made and I could smell the smoke coming from behind me. Behind me? That’s not right. I turned around quickly and the house was being engulfed in flames just like the wood pile. Our home was on fire. I sat up wide awake in my bed.

I jumped up and ran to my door and threw it open. I started out it towards Mama’s room but a searing pain in my left arm stopped me. The window above the stairs had always let in just the right amount of sunlight. Now it was a death trap for me.

“Mom!” I screamed. “Mom, wake up! The house is on fire.” I could smell the smoke coming from downstairs in the living room but there was a clear path to the kitchen she could get out. She came out of her room, still sleep fogged. “Go through the kitchen, it’s clear.”

“What about you?” she asked stalling at the top.

“Don’t worry about me!” I screamed. “Just go!” She went.

I looked at the light coming from the ceiling light, it was only 10 am I’d never be able to wait it out. I prayed one of our neighbors would call 911. Can a vampire still pray? I wasn’t sure, crosses and such didn’t really like us much. My prayers were answered, I heard the sirens coming.

The fire was under me and two room over. Two room full of extremely flammable memories; I had about 10 minutes before it would reach me. Fire not so much a problem, I could heal all the damage from that. The problem was the sunlight. How to get out of the house and survive. I could the firefighters now coming up the stairs calling me.

“Here I called, I’m in here!”

“Can you come out of the room at all?”

“No, there’s a shaft of light right outside my door. I’m trapped.”

“Stand back from the door, we’re coming in.”

I stood back from the door, away from the sunlight. They came through carrying a box shaped kind of like a coffin. This must be how they’re planning on getting me out of here, I thought, in a freaking box. You’ve got to be kidding me I thought as I climbed in and they locked it down over me. The box swayed sickeningly as they carried me down the stairs. I could feel the heat from the fire as they made their way out of the house.

We were taken to the hospital to be treated for any injuries. I was of course taken below to the vampire ward and let out of the damnable box finally. Sitting in the hospital bed fuming I was finally told that it had been arson. Someone in our neighborhood had set our house on fire. I was pissed. I wanted to know who but no one could tell me.

After dark I got Mom settled into a hotel and went back to find out who had set my home on fire. I walked up the driveway I had played in as a child and stared at the ruin of all my memories. I could feel the anger boiling up, turning me into a living torch, burning me in a way that was distinctly comforting. I would find this person and I would deal with them.

I started by the front corner of the living room, where they said the fire was started. I caught the scent of gasoline easily but underneath of that I could smell something else, fear. Whoever had done this had been terrified. I touched the ground out from where the gas had been poured. I rubbed it between my fingers and then touched my fingers too my nose, the smell hit me quickly. Jackie. My best friend had poured gasoline on my house and set it on fire. I could understand her being afraid to be around me but trying to kill me and my mother. That was another thing all together.

I straightened out of the crouch I was in and turned. Jackie’s house was only a few houses down from ours. It was extremely helpful when it came to sleep overs and study dates. And now it would be even more helpful in tracking her down. I walked down the sidewalk slowly, blending in the shadows of the trees over hanging it. I stopped just before I got to her driveway and stared. Her light was on and I knew that there was another window on the back of the house that I could get into more easily.

I climbed the lattice on the side of the house with a practiced ease and slipped in the window. Oh yeah, didn’t I tell you, that myth about a vampire having to be invited in is bs too. I landed on the top of the toilet in her private bathroom. Silently I stood up and moved into her room. Jackie was still downstairs with her family getting ready for bed. I looked at the clock on her desk, 8 pm, I had a couple of hours to wait. I looked around and found her diary. Of course I read it, quit looking so surprised. The entries over the last couple of week got progressively nastier about me and I realized that the attack that had turned me had broken her. That hurt, bad.

A quick update of Facebook and LJ, a look into her email and then she turned around. I was on her before she could scream. One hand covering her mouth, the other around her throat.

“You’ve been very naughty lately, Jackie-girl” I whispered in her ear using the childhood nickname. “You did something very bad to me and my mom, didn’t you?”

She bit down on my hand hard but I didn’t feel anything. Again, I could feel the strength coursing through my muscles and knew I could easily break her neck if I really wanted too. In the same instant, I knew I wouldn’t do it. I wasn’t a murderer, a monster.

“We’re going out the window, Jackie. I’m going to take you to the police station and you’re going to tell them what you did or I‘m going to do the same to your house.”

“Screw you, Gypsy. She shouldn’t have let a tainted monster like you back in her house. She was asking for it,” Jackie spit in my face when I moved my hand from her mouth. Reflexively I tightened the hand on her throat cutting of her diatribe before she could get started.

Before she could say or do anything, I reached in the drawer grabbed her diary and her and was out the window. I ran all the way to the station, never stopping, never slowing. I walked through the doors with Jackie walking sedately by my side, my fingers holding the back of her neck.

“I have information about the fire last night on Mason St.” I said to the desk clerk. She paged the detective working on the case and he came down right away.

“What’s this about, Miss Love?”

“Tell him,” I gave Jackie I shake and handed him her diary.

She told him what she had done. I think she believed me when I told her that I’d burn her house down. Jackie went to jail that night but she’ll be going somewhere a little less jail-esque and a little more psycho wardy. She really lost her mind when I became a vampire.

The insurance settlement on the house is going to buy us another one in a more vampire friendly neighborhood. It has an apartment in the basement that’s been set up perfectly for a vampire. There’s even a heat lamp type thing to help me get used to not being in the sunlight by giving me the heat and the light without the damaging effects of the UV rays. I like the apartment, gives me some more privacy and the feel of having my own place but keeps me close enough to Mom to keep her happy.

18 year old Gypsy Love meets Erick at the bar she works at. What she thought was going to be a great one night stand quickly turns into something else all together.


My grandfather used to collect maps, old maps. He had one that was his favorite; it had belonged to a pirate, on the edges past the charted areas was written “Here be dragons” in a beautiful flowing handwriting. I used to beg him to tell me stories of the dragons that warning told of and he told the most wonderful stories, tales of piracy and romance that I just couldn’t get enough of.

That was before I knew that the monsters of every little kids nightmare was real. Back before the vampires showed themselves to the world. Now everything is different. Oh, how I wish I was still that little girl.

My name is Gypsy Love and I’m dead. Well, not technically dead per say, it would be more accurate to say undead since I’m a vampire now. It hasn’t always been this way, I was a lively living girl just a few months ago. That was before Erick came into my bar. Erick, now there’s a man to turn a girl’s head; tall, lean, handsome, pale.

“Hi, can I get you a drink?” I said bouncing up next to him. I was a waitress in a little hole in the wall bar.

“Sure,” he said, his voice like dark velvet. “How about a coke?”

“Not a problem. I’ll be right back with it.” I walked away through the crowd that was already gathering. It was early on a Friday night so I knew it would only get worse.

Making my way back over to him I had plenty of time to admire the view. Good genetics I thought, nice strong jaw line, very masculine. His eyes were wide and a little deep set, the color of new leaves in the spring. I was betting he was close to six feet tall; lean, hard muscle covered every inch of his body as far as I could tell. I was almost drooling by the time I got to his side.

“Here you go, darlin,” I said, smiling and flipping my pony tail back over my shoulder.

“What’s your name?” he asked softly.

“Gypsy,” I answered him. “My mom was a hippy.”

“Gypsy,” he rolled my name around on his tongue making something low in my belly tighten. “When do you get off?” He hung around doing nothing the whole night but watching me until the bar closed and then he waited for me outside. If you had told me what would be waiting for me outside, I don’t think it would have changed anything.

When I walked up to him he slid an arm around my back pulling me in tight against his chest. He crushed his lips against mine and I didn’t fight him. I didn’t know what I was doing but I didn’t want to stop either. I melted against him and wrapped my arms around his neck.

“I’m Erick,” he said when he pulled back from me smiling. Sighing I leaned forward pressing my breasts harder against him and ran my fingers through his soft hair and then down in a line from his neck to the waistband of his jeans. He smelled so good.

Erick stepped around me pulling me back toward the side of the building. Once around the corner he pressed me between himself and the bricks. I could feel him, hard and excited through my skirt and I wanted him. He gave me what I wanted, what I was all but begging for, in a fast rush. Then things started to change, he was being too rough. I tried to push away from the wall but he was too strong for me, stronger than anyone I had ever seen. I felt the sharp nip of his fangs against my neck and I realized exactly how much trouble I was in.

I gathered my breath to scream and just before I could he struck like a fist slamming into my neck. The pain was so intense I couldn’t believe it. I closed my eyes and could feel my life draining away from me one suck at a time. It continued for longer than I could have imagined before he backed away and turned me around. When I opened my eyes, he was standing in front of me, my blood covering his face and his own wrist bleeding. I tried to fight him off again but I was too weak.

The will to live took over and I drank what he offered. His blood slid down my throat thickly coating everything inside me. My stomach cramped trying to reject the unnatural liquid filling it and slowly my body began to change. I thought the pain of his bite was bad but it was nothing compared to this. It felt like I was on fire. The last thing I saw was him laughing as he walked away and then I passed out.

The next thing I knew I was lying on a gurney with handcuffs locking my wrists to the guard rails. I pulled against them and felt the metal of the rails give just the slightest. That wasn’t right, I shouldn’t be able to bend metal. A sound by the door drew my attention and I looked to find a strange man standing in the doorway of what could only be the vampire ward of Tampa General Hospital.

“Who are you? Why am I in the vault?” I said feeling my throat tighten around the words, it hurt so badly and I felt like I hadn’t had a drop of water in days.

“To answer your second question. You’re here because you were attacked by a rogue vampire and changed. We had to put you in here until you could get control of yourself,” the man said. “As for the first, I’m Simon. I guess you could call me a counselor of sorts. I’m here to help newborns when they first wake up.”

“Wait, what do you mean, I was changed. I’m a fucking vampire now?” I screamed pulling harder on the restraints. “Let me out of here, I need to go home!”

“Of course but please calm down before you hurt yourself. You’ve just woken up so you’re still somewhat weak,” Simon pleaded with me. “Gypsy, please, you’re family has been informed and they’re waiting for you at home. Your car is in the parking lot, I’ll take you to it but first you must calm yourself.”

I stopped fighting when he came over to unlock the cuffs. Afterward, I just lay there for a few moments staring at the ceiling. “How could a one night stand have ended so badly? My mother is never going to let me hear the end of this,” I sighed.

I went home and got the expected lecture from my mother. I was called the next evening by a very nice detective who informed me that it wasn’t just a rogue vampire but a serial killer. He was caught the night after he attacked me. Apparently I had been a slightly raving lunatic for a few nights while the insanity that he held worked its way through my body and mind and everything settled inside me. It has been a very nasty scene that ended with Erick as a real and truly dead corpse.

Now, I’m a vampire. It’s a slightly heady thing being vulnerable only to sunlight and holy items. It did put a slight dampener on my social life, it seems my friends don’t exactly trust me not to kill them. Don’t really know that I blame them, they suddenly smell way too good; if you know what I mean. I lost my job when I threw a customer through the window for grabbing my ass, guess my boss didn’t like it when I did that. So hear I am, trying to get used to the extra strength, better hearing, better sense of smell, and just generally everything; I’m having to completely relearn everything and rethink my whole life.

I guess I’m going to go explore those uncharted areas of the map after all. I wonder if that old pirate was right and there really are dragons beyond those borders.

"Mommy, no!" a tiny voice screams at me in the middle of my tirade and I stop dead in my tracks. My almost 4 year old daughter scolds me without knowing it for not controling myself better.

I am that misfire in your brain

I am an almost 26 year old bi-polar woman. I make excuses for myself; I use my chemical imbalance as a crutch to explain away my constant instability. I try and try to control myself, but I always seem to slip at some point.

That makes you feel out of control

I have to force myself to leave my bedroom, let alone my home. I'm really quite terrified of what is outside my door. It seems that I can't go one day without fighting with my parents. Something always ends up happening that pisses someone off. When it happens I can never seem to control my tongue. I've never had an inner monologue button or a filter between brain and mouth but I used to be able to stop stuff on the tip of my tongue before it spills out. Not any more.

I am that chemical inside your head

What is this chemical in my head? What is it that won't let me be sane again?

That refuses to let you go

Whatever it is, it won't let me go. It has me in grip as hard as steel and I can't see a way out.

I am Bi Polar

I am bi polar. I fight an uphill battle both coming and going on a daily basis. I hardly ever sleep but I'm always tired. I lay awake at night listening to my brain tell my little lies to break me down. I drag myself through the days arguing with my brain, fighting against the lies. Fighting to breathe, fighting to live, fighting to one day be free.

“I can't do this right now!” I screamed at him. “I have a test Monday that I have to study for.” With that I turned and went down stairs to the computer room that doubled as my study. Mama and Daddy were both out, Mama at the hospital working and Daddy on the road driving. I was alone with him, the man I married, the man who was going to kill me.

My husband, Richard wasn't the greatest choice I could make. Actually he was the worst. I married him because I was stupid and young. We'd been married for four years by now and all of those four years had been full of pain and heartache. Miscarriages, still births and one child that died at only a year old, I hadn't really gotten over that but I was forcing myself to move on. I was in school, trying to follow in my mother's footsteps and be a wonderful nurse.

The operative word there being trying, it wasn't going so well. The abuse Richard put me through was taking quite a toll on me and my school work. I found it difficult to concentrate on my studies with broken ribs and quite a trial to write with my right wrist broken and in a cast.

I was thoroughly absorbed in my anatomy book when an arm slid around my throat and cut off the air that I needed to live. I scratched and clawed at the arm and I could feel my long nails tearing through the skin on his arm. I tried to scream around the pressure on my larynx but it barely came out as a whisper. The world started to get a black haze over it and I knew if I let the world go completely black I would never see it again. I fought harder, reaching up behind me I raked my nails across his eyes and welcomed the pained growl I heard come from him.

The python like arm loosened enough for me to get away and threw my chair back into his chest knocking the wind from him. I ran. Did I run out the door you ask. No, I didn't. I ran for the closest weapon I could find, my mother's favorite kitchen knife. What? Why didn't I run out the door like a smarter woman would? I never said I was smart; actually, I knew that if he didn't die that night, I would at some point. So I was going to finish it myself and put him out of my misery permanently. Hey, again, I never said I was smart.

I was in the kitchen before he ever regained his breath and came for me. I had the knife in my hand, sharp, so sharp. I hid in the corner waiting for him. I saw Richard's shadow as he came toward the door way. I waited til he was all the way in the room and past me before I struck out with the knife and slashed across his back. I screamed my fear and rage at him but it was only a whisper, my larynx was bruised. I fought him for my life and my freedom. I knew how to use a knife to defend myself. I made several nice cuts on his body but he was still stronger and faster than me.

He rushed me. He caught me off guard and got inside my reach and threw me against the counter. The world sparkled and danced in front of my eyes. Before I knew what was happening he had the knife away from me. My only defense against him was now betraying me. Still I fought him, fought with all I had in me but it just wasn't enough.

In one of those moments where it seems like you have all the time in the world he back handed me hard across my right eye and I was down. I saw it coming, I saw the flurry of kicks he rained down on me. I could appreciate the way his muscled moved and bunched as he buried his foot over and over in my stomach.

“Please... no more...” I choked out.

“What, bitch?”

“I'm sorry. I shouldn't have screamed at you, I'm sorry.”

“I just bet you are, cunt. I'm going to make you remember who the boss is this time.” And he kicked me in the face. I could hear my nose shatter at the same time my left cheek did. I knew it was almost over. I was going to die right there in my mother's kitchen.

“Get up,” Richard screamed pulling me to my knees by my hair, hair that was already tangled with blood and tears, and pulled my head back. I cried. I'm not ashamed of it, I did.

“I love you,” he said in a dead empty voice as he put the cold steel blade against the soft flesh of my throat. He pressed the blade harder and stopped for just a second before sliding in an arc around my throat.

This was it, I could feel the scalding heat of the blood flowing down my chest. He dropped me and the knife then turned away. I lay on the floor drowning and bleeding to death watching him. I knew he had only cut one blood vessel so it would take a couple minutes for me to bleed out. I knew there was nothing I could do but I still lifted my hand to my neck and tried to stop the bleeding. Then he turned back to me and picked up the knife again and buried it to the handle in my heart.

I stood there looking at my body in disbelief. I'm dead I thought sadly but he was speaking to my body, “This is your fault, you know, if you had just listened.” That bastard had just murdered me and was blaming me? I screamed at him, I beat my fists against his back but he didn't even notice. He just kept right on talking to my body, “Oh, Jessica, I love you but look what you made me do, you had to be taught a lesson that you wouldn't be able to forget.”

I heard a sound behind me and turned to see my mother standing the doorway with her gun pulled and the paramedics behind her. Without saying a word she pulled the trigger and ran to my body. The paramedics did what they do best and tried to save me. All of them kneeling in my blood, ignoring my husband who couldn't be helped. Mama don't miss when she aims her gun, and she aimed right between his eyes.

I guess it was all just a worthless and empty gesture for him to try to kill me, cause here I am.  Oh I died that night for all of ten minutes but I didn't stay dead.  Guess it sucks to be him though cause he sure didn't wake back up.
